title: WHZZ
text:
WHZZ (101.7 FM, "Mike FM") is a <a href="radio%20station">radio station</a> licensed to <a href="Lansing%2C%20Michigan">Lansing, Michigan</a> with a <a href="variety%20hits">variety hits</a> format.
History.
The station has gone through many different formats over the years. After beginning as a simulcast of <a href="WILS">WILS</a> 1320 AM as WILS-FM in 1967, the station separated programming in the late 1960s with an automated <a href="middle%20of%20the%20road%20%28music%29">MOR</a> format (with the exception of the Jerry Marshall morning show, which was simulcast with WILS-AM from 6 to 10 am). In 1972, WILS-FM launched an automated Country format which was branded as "Hit Country", although the morning simulcast continued. In 1975, WILS-FM abandoned the Country format in favor of a 12-hour daily simulcast with WILS-AM, followed by split programming in the evening, which included an <a href="Album%20Oriented%20Rock">AOR</a> format from 6 pm to midnight, and a <a href="Jazz">Jazz</a> format from midnight to 6 am. In 1978, WILS-FM abandoned the overnight Jazz and ended the simulcast with WILS-AM, programming the AOR format full time and somehow the AOR format proved to quite successful for the station, resulting in respectable ratings despite WILS-FM's 3KW signal.
In August 1983 WILS-AM and WILS-FM's original owner Lansing Broadcasting, sold the station to Sentry Broadcasting (a division of <a href="Sentry%20Insurance">Sentry Insurance</a>) The new management made changes quickly, deciding to automate sister station WILS-AM with a <a href="Nostalgia">Nostalgia</a> format, and then in December 1983 most of the WILS-FM air staff including the highly rated morning team of Douglas "Doug" Burton and Danny "Dan" Ballard were let go. And they were replaced by announcers from WILS-AM. And four months later on April the 14th of 1984 WILS-FM somwhow abruptly changed into an <a href="Adult%20Contemporary">AC</a> format using the brand name "The All New WILS FM 102" to compete with top-rated <a href="WFMK">WFMK</a>. The station's ratings plummeted and would not recover for over a decade as 101.7 FM went through unsuccessful tries at <a href="Hot%20Adult%20Contemporary">Hot AC</a> as WKKP and then later as WLYY and Country formats (the latter with a return to the WILS-FM calls in the early 1990s). The station also went through a number of ownership changes during this period. <a href="Sentry%20Insurance">Sentry Insurance</a> dissolved their radio division and sold WILS to Northstar Broadcasting in 1986 and after going through an upper-management shakeup Northstar sold the station to the now current owner <a href="MacDonald%20Broadcasting">MacDonald Broadcasting</a> in 1989.
In the spring of 1995, WILS-FM became WHZZ under their new moniker "The New Z101.7 FM", WHZZ filled the void as the new <a href="Contemporary%20Hit%20Radio">CHR</a>/<a href="Mainstream%20Top%2040">Top 40</a> station to for Lansing after 94.9 <a href="WMMQ">WVIC-FM</a> dropped its longtime CHR format to compete with country market leader <a href="WITL">WITL</a>. Z101.7 was frequently criticized by CHR aficionados for featuring an overly conservative adult-oriented playlist heavy on Hot AC chart currents and 1980's and 1990's gold, but the station enjoyed good Arbitron ratings during their CHR/Top 40 run and even reached #1 overall (12+) at least once.
On September 13, 2005, WHZZ unexpectedly flipped to <a href="adult%20hits">adult hits</a> as "Mike FM". Two days after WHZZ's flip, the CHR format was picked up by 97.5 <a href="WJIM-FM">WJIM-FM</a>.
